conflictDescription: User Story A requires communication only after explicit client consent, while User Story B requires automatic enforcement of consent policies without asking users, which may bypass explicit user agreement. These goals partially conflict because automatic enforcement without user prompts can contradict the need for explicit client agreement.
conflictingNfrPairs: Only communicate with clients after they give consent
Automatically apply consent policies without user prompts
Avoid contacting clients without their agreement
Automatically apply consent policies without user prompts
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to communicate with clients only when they agree, so I respect their privacy and comfort.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to enforce consent policies automatically to keep caregiver workflows secure without asking users.

conflictDescription: Some caregiver control over data use on shared devices may require exceptions or flexibility in consent enforcement, which conflicts with strict no-exception enforcement of consent rules by the developer.
conflictingNfrPairs: Allow informal caregiver to set data use rules on shared devices
Enforce all consent rules without exceptions
Prevent data mix-ups between different users on shared devices
Prevent caregiver tasks if consent is not given
Protect clients' privacy when ALFRED is used on shared devices
Ensure caregiver tasks always follow consent rules
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control ALFRED’s data use on shared devices at home, so I can protect my clients’ privacy and avoid mix-ups.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to enforce consent rules strictly without exceptions, so caregiver tasks are always done right.
